ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about the vast, interdisciplinary field of sound studies. This course changed the way I think about sound, the sonic environment around me, and the audio technologies we use.
A lot about various sub-disciplines of sound studies: soundscape analysis, historical soundscapes, audio technological history, and modes of listening.

Gained a general overview of the field of sound studies by focusing on individual aspects of the field at a time such as historical soundscapes, or audio technology. We looked at these topics not just at face value, but also at how they impact communication, interpersonal relations, personal boundaries, and society as a whole.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The discussions based on the readings would often go on super specific tangents, and sometimes there lacked a clear direction for the discussion. The readings were generally fun, however, and the assignments were engaging.

I feel like this course suffered from being in a virtual format  it wasn't very discussion-y and often Prof. Kane would lecture, which is great he's a great professor and super knowledgeable  but I wish there was more discussion because one of the highlights of the course was definitely the reading. Really interesting stuff that I enjoyed a lot!

The course is formatted so that class discussions can go wherever the students take it. This makes for a very fun class to be in that is extremely low stress since most topics up for discussion have no right or wrong answer. I do however think the course would benefit from some questions to consider with each reading or some other type of guided activity to go along with the readings just to help facilitate discussion since so many of the readings are on topics that the students have never covered or maybe never thought about.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course, during a pandemic, should be more structured or should not be this long. I had trouble staying engaged for the entire discussion.

I think that an open discussion seminar will always be better in person than online, however professor Kane does a good job at encouraging discussion from as many people with as many viewpoints as possible.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes!!!! Professor Kane is amazing and very passionate and knowledgeable on Sound Studies. The readings are interesting and seminar discussions were always engaging  and completely led by students. You definitely take away what you put into the course, which is not much if you dont interact with the readings or participate in class. But if youre interested in a niche subject that is also relevant and very connected with music and the world, take this class for sure!
Yes if you're fairly interested in sound studies or if you're a music major looking to satisfy a group IV credit. There are a lot of readings though and the course gets a bit philosophical.

Yes, but: beware. Even though it's termed 'Introduction to Sound Studies', there is a lot of really dense media theory in the reading. I felt pretty bad for a couple of high schoolers who were enrolled in the class  the material can be pretty intense at times. Some background in philosophy/aesthetics/critical theory is definitely helpful in advance of the course.

I would recommend this course to other students because it is a great chance to get to study an interdisciplinary field that requires virtually no background to enjoy. The assigned workload is very minimal but you get out of this course exactly what you put into it so if you are willing to engage in readings and discussions it is a very fun and interesting course.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
